title: 'It broke my heart': Chris Hughes admits it was 'difficult' to watch Jesy Nelson's trolling ordeal
text:
Chris Hughes has admitted that it was 'difficult' to watch girlfriend Jesy Nelson's trolling ordeal in her documentary Odd One Out, stating that 'it broke my heart'.

In a new interview with Happiful magazine, The Love Island star, 26, also opened up about his long-term battle with anxiety in which he frequently suffered panic attacks from the age of 19.

Following a course of hypnotherapy, the hunk was anxiety-free during his time in the famous villa, but told how anxiety re-entered his life a months ago.

Hard: Chris Hughes has admitted that it was 'difficult' to watch girlfriend Jesy Nelson's trolling ordeal in her documentary Odd One Out, stating that 'it broke my heart'

Discussing how the anxiety increased in severity while he was drunk on holiday with the Little Mix beauty, Chris said: 'For the last three or four days of my holiday, I couldn't shake the anxiety, and I started feeling really low and down.'

He revealed that he sought the help of a clinical hypnotherapist once again, who recommended that he practise self-care, with Chris stating that he makes every effort to 'eliminate negative thoughts.'

Luckily, the reality star can share his worries with girlfriend Jesy, who knows only too well what he's going though after suffering with anxiety and depression herself as a result of cruel trolling at the height of her X Factor fame.

Her ordeal was televised in a BBC documentary, Odd One Out, last month, in which she revealed that the horrendous abuse she received drove her to attempt suicide.

Tough: In a new interview with Happiful magazine, The Love Island star, 26, opened up about his battle with anxiety in which he frequently suffered panic attacks from the age of 19

Speaking about how tough it was to see his love's suffering, Chris explained: 'It broke my heart. It was difficult to watch. Just seeing all the things she has been through and overcome, she deserves every bit of happiness now.'

The racing presenter revealed that he and the Black Magic hitmaker have a 'deep understanding' and can 'relate' to each others issues.

Chris, who spoke with Happiful to raise awareness of Movember, has continued to work on his mental wellness and emphasised how important it is to get people talking about mental health - especially men.

Honest chat: 'For the last three or four days of my holiday, I couldn't shake the anxiety, and I started feeling really low and down'

Chris’ full interview is in the November issue of Happiful on sale Thursday 17 October

'Many men feel that speaking about their feelings is a vulnerability, a weakness,' he said. 'But I’ve always seen the benefits in it. It’s little obstacles… you’re not going to be happy every day of your life; it’s normal to have low points.'

He added that he wants to 'shake' anxiety and is attempting to do all he can in terms of his lifestyle to make himself 'feel better'.

Chris has previously opened up about his mental health issues, revealing in 2017 that he used to dread going home after work as his mind would no longer be occupied.

He told The Mirror: 'Then it was weird, that feeling, because for the first time you start to realise why there's suicide and that's the worst thing about it. I was going to work 9-5, and when I was occupied my mind was busy.

'I used to dread going home from work. I used to clock-watch from about 4pm and never wanted it to get to 5 o'clock, because I knew the moment I got home I'd be struggling again.'

He added: 'There was no trigger as far as I remember - I was almost anxious about being anxious, and that's why I didn't look forward to going home.'

Chris’ full interview is in the November issue of Happiful on sale Thursday 17 October.
description: The Love Island star, 26, admitted that it was 'difficult' to watch girlfriend Jesy Nelson's trolling ordeal and opened up about his long-term battle with anxiety.
